Application_Facts: Applicants' PRRA application was brief due to anticipation of permanent residence approval; after refusal of permanent residence, they did not update their PRRA submission; decision made 10 months later without new novel evidence
Residency_Compliance: Not in compliance – failed to update application despite opportunity
Procedural_Issue: Failure to notify applicants of reactivation of PRRA application and opportunity to submit supplementary information
Evidence_Used: Original PRRA application, no new 'novel' evidence presented
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of updated submissions from applicants despite ample opportunity
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that procedural fairness was violated
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: No breach of fairness found as applicants had ample opportunity to update their PRRA application but failed to do so

Application_Facts: PRRA and H&C applications were denied during volatile war conditions in Sri Lanka
Decision based on undisclosed BBC articles and a UK tribunal decision later deemed invalid
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose significant new developments
Lack of reasonable consideration of evidence
Evidence_Used: Undisclosed BBC articles
UK tribunal decision (later invalidated)
Decision_Outcome: Denial of PRRA and H&C applications
Outcome: Applications for judicial review allowed
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of applications by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to disclose key information and relied on invalid precedent; decision made under unreasonable circumstances due to timing amid conflict in Sri Lanka

Crimes.Violation_Type: Deportation due to criminal activity by family member
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's husband deported due to criminal activity; applicant sought deferral of removal based on child's best interests
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to prior failed refugee claims
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of expulsion officer’s decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, H&C claims, child welfare considerations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer considered claims but found no impediment to removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and consideration of child's best interests
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Enforcement as soon as reasonably practicable under s.48 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal or humanitarian impediment justified deferral

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal to defer removal due to alleged lost H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether officer erred in failing to consider child's best interests and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of risk and lost application deemed unsubstantiated
Crimes.Evidence_Type: H&C application status, allegations of abuse
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, domestic violence risks
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence supporting risk and document loss
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misplacement of documents, not proven fraud

Crimes.Violation_Type: Continued stay after visa expiration following rejected refugee claims
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed after unsuccessful refugee claims; sought deferral due to personal risks and Canadian-born child
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of refusal to defer removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA rejection, H&C application status, child’s citizenship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence or valid H&C application submitted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Risks not substantiated; claims lacked timeliness and support
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Removal as soon as reasonably practicable
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal barrier or compelling humanitarian factor warranted delay

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Family unity considered as factor in removal decision
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Alleged ongoing abuse, not criminally prosecuted
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as unsubstantiated due to lack of timely evidence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threat from abusive spouse upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient – claims raised late without documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, H&C application claims
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to timing and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not fully accepted by officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Consideration under H&C and child’s best interests in IRPA framework

Application_Facts: Mr. Cirahan, a Turkish Kurdish Alevi, claimed protection in Canada, arguing he faces persecution upon return to Turkey.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the PRRA decision, analysis of submitted evidence and Officer's reasoning
Evidence_Used: Goven Letter and other documentary evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of substantiation, outdated information, interested nature of the source
Credibility_Assessment: PRRA Officer gave little weight to submitted documents due to credibility concerns
Decision_Outcome: PRRA Officer concluded not all Kurdish Alevis face persecution in Turkey
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Protection in Canada based on risk of persecution
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of PRRA decision through judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of country conditions and risk of persecution
Decision_Rationale: PRRA Officer's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence; risks assessed thoroughly

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate new risk conditions
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 115 and Section 101(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed rape-related scars as new evidence; RPD had previously considered rape allegations; no significant new evidence or personalized risk identified in Albania
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of consideration of new evidence on gender-based violence and procedural fairness in PRRA decision
Evidence_Used: Rape-related scars, allegations of gender-based violence, risk of blood feud in Albania
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No significant new evidence presented; prior allegations already assessed by RPD
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found no credible, individualized risk based on new evidence
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no error found in Officer's decision
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA denial, stay of removal
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question of law; judicial review of PRRA decision
Decision_Rationale: PRRA not an appeal of RPD decision; requires demonstration of changed circumstances; no new evidence of personalized risk established

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visas and sought refugee protection, which was refused. They applied for humanitarian and compassionate consideration and requested deferral of removal.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary residents with expired status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Refusal to defer removal despite pending H&C application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal to defer removal by enforcement officer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on pending H&C application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of refusal to defer removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness doctrine: existence of a live controversy
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No live controversy remained after the scheduled removal date passed and a stay of removal was granted. The deferral was effectively in place via the stay, rendering the issue abstract.
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) enforcement officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants were subject to a removal order but remained in Canada due to a court-issued stay. They sought deferral based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds, which was denied.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Removed persons under formal removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Remained in Canada contrary to removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Denial of deferral request prior to removal date; judicial review filed after removal date passed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Pending humanitarian and compassionate application, court-issued stay of removal
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Enforcement officer denied deferral of removal
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of refusal to defer removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness: absence of practical effect or ongoing controversy
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: The removal date passed without execution of removal, and applicants remained in Canada under a stay. No live issue remained for adjudication.
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) enforcement officer

Risk_Assessment: Danger to the public under s. 115(2)(a)

Legal_Issue: Proper consideration of evidence and procedural fairness
Outcome: Remitted for reassessment of country conditions risk

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Findings upheld except risk assessment
Risk_Nature: Public danger despite no recent convictions

Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider country condition evidence
Evidence_Used: Criminal history, gang affiliation, behavioral patterns
Evidentiary_Deficiency: May 2006 submissions on Sri Lanka ignored
Credibility_Assessment: Pattern of behavior supports danger finding
Outcome: Remitted for risk reassessment

Dispute_Type: Deportation based on drug-related organized crime
Risk_Nexus: Link between past behavior and future danger
Outcome: Risk assessment remitted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using a firearm to commit an offence
Possession of a weapon dangerous to the public
Risk_Nature: Continuing threat due to criminal pattern

Prior_Criminality: History of criminal and gang activity
Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as part of behavioral pattern

Credibility_Assessment: Reliance on non-conviction incidents found reasonable

Violation_Type: Procedural delay in processing permanent residence application
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 21(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant's permanent residence application delayed due to security inquiries and uncertainties regarding marital status; a cessation application was filed after the mandamus request
Residency_Compliance: Application pending; no final determination due to procedural bar
Procedural_Issue: Filing of cessation application during judicial review, triggering subsection 21(3) bar
Evidence_Used: Security inquiry records, marital status documentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Uncertainties in marital status affecting application assessment
Outcome: Application dismissed; no mandamus order granted
Relief_Sought: Mandamus order to compel processing of permanent residence application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandamus requires clear public duty, unreasonable delay, and absence of alternative remedy
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context of administrative decision
Decision_Rationale: Cessation application pending, which legally precludes approval of permanent residence under subsection 21(3); delays partially justified by security concerns
Authority_Responsible: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentation was present but overemphasized
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Application records, family circumstances, best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exemption from inadmissibility based on H&C factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Family reunification, best interests of children, integration in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25
Crimes.Application_Factor: Misrepresentation as a factor, not determinative
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by another officer
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or incomplete declaration in immigration application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependants in immigration application
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of dependants in sponsorship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Sponsor failed to declare wife and children upon arrival
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Excluded from family class due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Compliant with residency requirements in Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of dependants in initial application
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient consideration of H&C factors in decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess H&C claims
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, duration of stay, best interests of children
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of thorough analysis of humanitarian factors
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible despite sponsor's omission
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of H&C application by new officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under Section 25
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Overemphasis on misrepresentation, neglect of family reunification and children's best interests

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in assessing the applicant's risk of torture, death, or cruel treatment if returned to Pakistan
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence linking applicant's MQM-A membership to specific risks; claims were vague and lacked detail
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate personalized risk
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible, detailed evidence about threats or political involvement
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person in need of protection must face a personal risk not shared by others in their country under IRPA s.97
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of torture, death, or cruel treatment upon return to Pakistan due to MQM-A affiliation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's membership in MQM-A, alleged attack by MQM-H, resulting paraplegia, lack of documentation on direct threats
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer concluded no sufficient link between applicant’s activities and personal risk
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported political involvement, medical records (paraplegia), lack of third-party verification
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal based on risk of harm
Crimes.Authority: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk due to MQM-A membership and threats from MQM-H
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawful presence challenged due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – focus on credibility and evidence sufficiency
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether officer followed fair process in evaluating risk claims
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's statements on political involvement and attack
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence linking membership to personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed vague and unsubstantiated
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; removal not deferred
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as person in need of protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence to establish a personal risk distinct from general population
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer, subject to judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaged in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged membership in MQM-A, listed as terrorist entity
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Officer assessed whether applicant posed threat or was at risk due to involvement
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with politically active group involved in violence
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Political activism, alleged attack leading to paraplegia
Crimes.Target_Entity: Applicant allegedly targeted by rival faction (MQM-H)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant admitted MQM-A membership but denied militant role
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No evidence of leadership role provided
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Officer found applicant's account lacking in detail and corroboration
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to prove attacker identity or political motivation of attack
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-declarations, medical report, absence of police or witness records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Generalized claims without specific supporting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Vague descriptions of involvement and threats
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to alleged terrorist affiliation
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility finding, rejection of protection claim, eligibility for removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide sufficient evidence for refugee protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence to qualify as a person in need of protection
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Limited evidence on MQM-A role and threats; documentary country conditions not personally linked
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show personal risk upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of specific details about political activities or direct threats
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A person faces a need for protection if removal would result in torture, risk to life, or cruel treatment personally
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to political opinion and membership in particular social group
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical record of paraplegia, self-reported political affiliation, lack of corroborative evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer found no credible link between the attack and political activities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical documentation, lack of official reports
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Recognition as person in need of protection
Crimes.Outcome: Removal not stayed; proceedings allowed to continue
Crimes.Authority: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee definition under IRPA
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) - Refugee Status Provisions
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed past persecution in Mauritania based on ethnicity and imputed political opinion; Board found discrimination but not persecution; country conditions have changed, reducing future risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the Refugee Protection Division's rejection of refugee claim
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of country conditions in Mauritania, applicants' testimony, evidence of ethnic discrimination
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish persecution as opposed to discrimination
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on legal interpretation and reasonableness of decision
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Fear of persecution on enumerated grounds under IRPA; changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Board reasonably concluded that while there was evidence of discrimination, it did not amount to persecution; changed circumstances in Mauritania mitigate future risk; no compelling reasons to override country condition changes
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Application_Facts: Rathnayaka claimed refugee status due to threats for his involvement in the Peace Alliance; Board questioned credibility based on incorrect assumption that he reported an incident to police in May 2003 and speculated about security forces' capabilities.
Procedural_Issue: Patently unreasonable decision
Erroneous credibility assessment
Evidence_Used: Board's reasons
Claimant's testimony
Alleged police report (incorrectly assumed)
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility findings were based on factual errors and speculation, rendering them patently unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: Decision found to be patently unreasonable
Outcome: Case remanded to the Board for rehearing by a different panel
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Decision_Rationale: The Board made material factual errors and engaged in speculation, undermining the credibility assessment and overall fairness of the decision.

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer breached principles of fairness by not updating the application after a two-year delay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 113(a)
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred; PRRA decision stands
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged new risk was deemed implausible given prior RPD findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of new or updated evidence from applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Claim of increased personal risk upon return to home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to provide updated information during the delay
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to update application with new circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None — no new evidence was submitted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers must assess new evidence but are not required to solicit updates
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application rejected due to lack of new evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 113(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar remained in Canada after her visa expired while pursuing protection claims
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable — violation based on status, not false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PRRA decision and removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA application, lack of updated submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide new evidence supporting continued stay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Increased risk claim unsubstantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on PRRA application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for PRRA, correctness for jurisdictional issues
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural unfairness; applicant had opportunity to update but did not

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Tovar failed to depart Canada after final removal order was issued
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged oral deferral request not documented or acknowledged
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of removal process
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal interview records, absence of written deferral request
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of formal deferral request
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of oral deferral request not accepted
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order remains valid and enforceable
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Set aside removal order or defer removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No duty to defer without clear request or practical impediment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Suspected fraudulent marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was violated in assessing credibility of relationship
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision upheld; no procedural breach found
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Relationship claims lacked corroboration and consistency
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of updated documentation or communication records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return due to changed personal circumstances
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide new evidence supporting genuine relationship
Crimes.Application_Error: Did not disclose or substantiate marital status changes
Crimes.Legal_Standard: PRRA officers assess risk based on submitted evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of denied refugee claim and lack of cooperation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicion of sham marriage not proven but contributed to credibility concerns

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in PRRA and removal processes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PRRA and removal officers respected natural justice
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on existing record; no duty to seek new evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent claims and lack of follow-up
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Officers must act fairly but are not required to prompt applicants for updates
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Two-year delay, alleged oral deferral request
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of updated submissions or formal deferral request
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CBSA and IRCC maintained decisions were procedurally fair
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written PRRA application, removal interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 113(a), IRPA; common law procedural fairness

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Assessment of cumulative persecution in PRRA under IRPA
Application_Facts: Officer acknowledged individual risks but failed to assess them cumulatively in the PRRA decision, unlike in the H&C decision
Claimant_Status: Applicant claiming refugee protection, denied; subsequent H&C and PRRA applications rejected
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider cumulative persecution in PRRA assessment, raising procedural fairness concerns
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Omission of cumulative risk analysis despite existence of multiple discriminatory acts
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C decisions set aside; judicial review allowed
Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by a different officer
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA and H&C applications
Legal_Standard_Applied: Officers must assess risks cumulatively if multiple discriminatory acts exist under IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Failure to assess cumulative persecution could have affected the outcome of the PRRA decision
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer responsible for PRRA and H&C decisions

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 96-97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian jurisprudence on well-founded fear of persecution
Application_Facts: Mr. Mete is a Christian convert claiming persecution in Turkey due to religious discrimination
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider cumulative effect of discriminatory acts
Evidence_Used: Credible testimony, evidence of harm to Christians in Turkey
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of cumulative impact of discrimination
Outcome: Decision set aside on judicial review
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of claim by new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution, including cumulative persecution test
Decision_Rationale: Persecution includes repeated or cumulative discriminatory acts; RPD erred by analyzing incidents in isolation
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section related to valid visa duration under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in the country beyond the authorized period of stay and were subject to a removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review rendered academic due to stay order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa records, removal order documentation, court stay order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal and judicial review
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and reconsideration of deferral request
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue type
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Stay order halted removal, making the original judicial review application academic

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Enforcement provisions under IRPA regarding removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants challenged the denial of deferral of removal after a stay was granted by the court
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review rendered academic due to stay order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration enforcement decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order, deferral request, judicial stay order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of enforcement decision and deferral of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and reversal of deferral denial
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Stay of removal eliminated live controversy, rendering the matter moot
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer's refusal of the Applicants' humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application was justified under section 25 of IRPA
Outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed
Evidence_Type: Integration, employment, community involvement, children’s circumstances
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds to avoid unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No exceptional hardship found; best interests of children considered
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness, transparency, and legal discretion under IRPA
Application_Factor: Family establishment in Canada, integration into society

Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas, integrated into Canadian society, have two children
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons, proper test application, evidence consideration
Evidence_Used: Integration, family ties, potential hardships to children
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship under s. 25 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: No unusual hardship established despite family ties and integration

Violation_Type: Procedural violation - failure to provide oral hearing
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Application_Facts: Ms. Wilson claimed a risk of mistreatment in Jamaica based on her sexual orientation; application was rejected due to insufficient evidence
Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident applying for Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA) and Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) considerations
Procedural_Issue: Adverse credibility findings made without granting an oral hearing as required under IRPR s 167
Evidence_Used: Claimant's testimony and supporting documentation regarding risk in Jamaica
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence cited by officer as basis for dismissal
Credibility_Assessment: Officer implicitly questioned Ms. Wilson's credibility by dismissing claims for lack of evidence, constituting adverse credibility finding
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C applications initially refused
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for reassessment by a different panel
Relief_Sought: Allowance of PRRA and H&C applications, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Oral hearing on PRRA application, reassessment of both PRRA and H&C applications
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious credibility issues central to application trigger right to oral hearing under IRPR s 167
Decision_Rationale: Implicit adverse credibility findings require oral hearing under IRPR s 167; failure to provide one renders decision unreasonable
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court (judicial review)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed statelessness and risk of persecution in Pakistan
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application filed challenging IRB's decision
Evidence_Used: IRB considered evidence regarding ability to acquire Pakistani citizenship and lack of credible persecution risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting statelessness or persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims found not credible by IRB
Outcome: Court dismissed judicial review application
Relief_Sought: Overturning of IRB decision on refugee status
Decision_Rationale: Applicant could acquire Pakistani citizenship and failed to provide sufficient evidence of persecution

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence in Canada during the four years preceding the application while studying abroad
Residency_Compliance: No, failed to accumulate 1,095 days of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal reviewed and dismissed by Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required residency duration
Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residence within four years prior to application under Section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Appellant did not meet statutory residency requirement due to prolonged absence from Canada for studies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Knowingly Concealing Material Circumstances in Immigration Process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Odynsky served as an auxiliary guard at Nazi labor camps during WWII and did not disclose this when applying for Canadian citizenship.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Complied with residency requirements but obtained status through concealment
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose wartime activities that were material to admissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Proceedings initiated by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian citizenship law
Evidence_Used: Testimonies from experts and contemporaries
Historical documents
Security screening records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct documentation of disclosure during initial immigration screening
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found Odynsky's explanation less credible than evidence indicating concealment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deprivation of citizenship under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Admission to Canada was based on failure to disclose material wartime involvement that would have led to rejection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation based on false representation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Odynsky obtained citizenship through false representation or concealment of material facts
Crimes.Outcome: Citizenship declared obtained by false representation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found it more probable than not that Odynsky misrepresented or concealed his wartime role
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Involuntary service with German auxiliary forces and failure to disclose during immigration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Likelihood that disclosure would have resulted in denial of entry
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative hearing under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose material wartime activities on immigration and citizenship applications
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; court relied on available historical and testimonial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: False representation or knowingly concealing material circumstances under s. 10 and s. 18
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and extent of collaboration with Nazi forces
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Declaration that citizenship was obtained by false representation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct document forgery, but omission constituted fraudulent misrepresentation

Application_Facts: Applicant sustained a thumb injury in 1999; worked regularly until 2004; post-MQP diagnosis of delusional disorder
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PAB's decision denying appeal rights
Evidence_Used: Medical records, work history, PAB assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing severe and prolonged disability by December 31, 2001
Decision_Outcome: PAB concluded no arguable case for disability benefits
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed without costs
Legal_Standard_Applied: Severe and prolonged disability as of minimum qualifying period (MQP); 'arguable case' test
Decision_Rationale: Thumb injury did not meet CPP disability criteria by MQP; post-MQP conditions irrelevant; applicant continued working

Application_Facts: Ms. Adams claimed refugee protection due to fear of abuse in Trinidad and St. Vincent.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed the Board’s decision on state protection and Gender Guidelines application.
Evidence_Used: Recent reports indicating improved mechanisms for addressing domestic violence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Limited evidence provided by Ms. Adams about state protection in Trinidad and St. Vincent
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing Board's interpretation of country conditions and Gender Guidelines
Decision_Rationale: The Board reasonably assessed country conditions and applied Gender Guidelines; state protection mechanisms were deemed adequate based on recent reports.

Application_Facts: Varadi, a Roma lesbian, claimed persecution in Hungary and sought refugee protection in Canada; officer failed to assess cumulative risk and state protection adequacy
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear reasoning, omission of key evidence, inadequate analysis of cumulative persecution and state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence of persecution based on sexual orientation and ethnic minority status
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer omitted key details and failed to assess relevance of evidence to Varadi's circumstances
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; original decision quashed
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of PRRA by a different immigration officer
Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked sufficient reasoning, failed to consider all evidence and cumulative risks, and did not properly analyze state protection

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the applicant's low back pain was not service-related
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Board ignored uncontradicted evidence including medical records and Major Zaporzan's letter; dismissed post-1996 medical records without justification
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision quashed, matter remitted for reconsideration by a different panel
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish service-related injury
Credibility_Factor: Uncontradicted medical evidence and supporting letter from military officer
Legal_Rule: Board must consider all evidence favorably to the applicant and resolve doubts in their favor
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged lack of proper consideration of service-related injury evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Court found the Board erred in its assessment
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical records, Major Zaporzan's letter, post-1996 treatment history
Legal_Framework: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act, Federal Court Act
Evidence_Type: Medical records, official correspondence, clinical documentation
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of Board decision, re-determination by new panel
Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, remitted for re-determination
Legal_Provision: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act provisions on favorable interpretation and doubt resolution

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did MacGregor's actions constitute contempt of court by violating the interlocutory injunction?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed MacGregor wore the Barney costume, sang, danced, participated in photos, and sold balloons.
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Eyewitness testimony and media reports confirmed presence and performance as Barney
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt of personal knowledge of the order, being the primary actor, and mens rea.
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of copyrighted Barney character
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral evidence, eyewitness accounts, media reports
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of interlocutory injunction, legal costs
Crimes.Outcome: Fined $3,000 and ordered to pay up to $2,000 in legal costs
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Interlocutory injunction related to copyright protection
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did MacGregor's actions constitute contempt of court by violating the interlocutory injunction?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: MacGregor performed as Barney; no other impersonator present
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Eyewitness testimony and media reports supported violation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt occurs when a person disobeys a court order with requisite knowledge and intent.

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral evidence, investigative report
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Sanctions for breach of court order
Crimes.Outcome: Fined $3,000 and ordered to pay up to $2,000 in solicitor-client costs
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule regarding disobedience of court orders

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt of personal knowledge, agency, and intent.
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized representation as Barney causing confusion
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Liability established for passing off through unauthorized use
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Law of passing off and injunction enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Investigative report, observational evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of injunction and cost recovery
Crimes.Outcome: Fined $3,000 and ordered to pay up to $2,000 in legal costs
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Interlocutory injunction against unauthorized use of character
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did MacGregor's actions constitute contempt by violating the interlocutory injunction on Barney trademark usage?

Legal_Issue: Validity of the '784 Patent based on utility and obviousness-type double patenting
Procedural_Stage: Pre-trial injunction phase seeking prohibition of regulatory approval
Evidence_Assessment: Analysis of patent claims, expert testimony, prior art
Burden_of_Proof: On Mylan to prove invalidity of the patent
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony supporting sound prediction of utility
Legal_Rule: Utility must be demonstrated or soundly predicted at filing date; obviousness-type double patenting requires lack of novelty or ingenuity over earlier patent
Standard_of_Review: Balance of convenience and likelihood of success on merits
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of utility, obviousness-type double patenting
Outcome_on_Merits: The '784 Patent is valid and distinct from the '377 Patent
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art disclosing tadalafil as PDE V inhibitor, expert evidence on sound prediction, absence of clinical data at filing
Legal_Framework: Canadian Patent Act and jurisprudence on utility and double patenting
Defendant_Response: Mylan sought to invalidate the '784 Patent to market generic tadalafil
Remedy_Requested: Order prohibiting Mylan from receiving regulatory approval until patent expiry
Outcome: Court granted order, prohibiting Mylan from obtaining regulatory approval until patent expiration
Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions of Canadian Patent Law regarding utility and double patenting
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over patent disputes

Legal_Issue: Whether Procter & Gamble is entitled to an interlocutory injunction for alleged patent infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits from experts, lack of product sample, cross-examinations
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must show: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff established a prima facie case; defendant failed to refute evidence convincingly
Legal_Rule: Three-part test for interlocutory injunction: (a) serious issue to be tried, (b) irreparable harm, (c) balance of convenience favors plaintiff
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of patent by Colgate's Ultra Fleecy product prior to patent expiry
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; injunction granted pending trial or expiration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Expert affidavits, market launch plans, patent claims
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law and equitable principles for injunctive relief
Defendant_Response: Denied infringement; argued lack of evidence and no demonstrated harm
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to prevent sale of Ultra Fleecy
Outcome: Injunction granted; Colgate prohibited from selling Ultra Fleecy until patent expired
Legal_Provision: Interlocutory injunction provisions under Canadian equity and patent law
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over intellectual property disputes

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Refusal of spouse’s permanent residence application based on alleged non-genuine relationship
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Doubted authenticity of marriage based on inconsistencies and age difference
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded to another visa officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Spousal sponsorship based on alleged sham marriage
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the marriage was genuine or primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 4 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Outcome: Original decision set aside; remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Testimonies contained contradictions but supported by birth of child and ongoing contact
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered into for immigration advantage
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Presence of child, frequency of communication, cultural context
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Appeal Division, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Focus on irrelevant factors such as age difference and pre-marriage knowledge
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of shared life and interdependence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Genuine marital relationship required for sponsorship
Crimes.Application_Factor: Assessment of exclusivity, intimacy, interdependence, permanence, societal perception

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee status claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that Jamaica provides adequate state protection for women fearing violence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Adequate state protection requires both will and capacity to effectively implement laws protecting citizens from harm
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, matter remanded for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed; focus on systemic failure rather than individual credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: U.S. State Department reports on police reluctance and violence against women
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of violence from deported partner in Jamaica
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate implementation of protective laws despite their existence
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider evidence of ineffective state protection
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Existence of both governmental will and capacity to protect
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of police reluctance and widespread violence against women
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Adequate state protection requires effective implementation of laws
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant's fear of domestic violence upon return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board's decision set aside, case remanded

Crimes.Governing_Law: Adequate state protection requires both will and capacity to implement laws
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and claimed refugee status due to fear of violence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not directly alleged; focus on protection concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Proper assessment of state protection in home country
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Immigration Refugee Board over refugee claims
Crimes.Evidence_Used: U.S. State Department report on violence against women and police inaction
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to address evidence of ineffective law enforcement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; claim rejected on state protection grounds
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision set aside, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Refugee protection based on gender-based violence risk
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Effective implementation of laws required for adequate state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board focused on laws without assessing enforcement

Crimes.Victim_Status: Female applicant with history of abuse
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of violence, deportation of perpetrator increasing risk
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of serious harm or death
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm due to lack of state intervention
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Ongoing and specific threat from ex-partner
Crimes.Threat_Source: Former partner with history of violence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on relationship and gender
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – supported by U.S. reports and personal circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Country condition reports, personal testimony (implied)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as credible by reviewing court
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear of harm
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Refugee Convention grounds: membership in particular social group (women fearing domestic violence)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of rejection of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing adequacy of state protection in Jamaica
Crimes.Governing_Law: Adequate state protection requires both will and capacity to enforce laws
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear of violence deemed credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: U.S. State Department report on police reluctance and gender-based violence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to domestic violence and inadequate state protection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Government’s failure to effectively implement protective laws
Crimes.Application_Error: Board ignored evidence of ineffective enforcement of laws
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Effective implementation standard for state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of police reluctance and systemic failures in protecting women
Crimes.Legal_Standard: State must have both will and capacity to protect
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant’s membership in a particular social group (women fearing domestic violence)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision set aside, remanded for new hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Material Facts in Immigration Applications
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer reasonably consider humanitarian and compassionate grounds when denying the applicant's permanent residence application?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; visa officer's decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Parents' concealment of applicant's existence viewed as deceitful
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application records, personal circumstances of applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, including best interests of the child
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Balance between applicant's circumstances and parents' fraudulent actions
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose material fact (applicant's existence)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision under administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – officer considered all relevant factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Consideration of humanitarian and compassionate factors under s. 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Best interests of the child directly affected
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of permanent residence due to insufficient H&C grounds
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Concealment of material fact in immigration application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision to deny permanent resident status based on insufficient humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds was reasonable
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; visa officer's decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Parents' misrepresentation negatively impacted credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application records, personal circumstances of applicant
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Exemption from immigration requirements on H&C grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Balance between applicant's best interests and public policy concerns due to parental deceit
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation of facts in immigration applications
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision under administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found – officer properly weighed all factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: H&C considerations under Section 25(1), including best interests of the child
Crimes.Application_Factor: Impact of parental misrepresentation on eligibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of permanent residence due to insufficient H&C grounds
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Intentional misrepresentation in official immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer's decision to deny permanent resident status based on insufficient humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds violate the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certified question proposed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Parental fraudulent conduct significantly undermined application legitimacy
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application records, evidence of non-disclosure or false statements
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request for exemption under H&C considerations despite inadmissibility due to fraud
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Weighing of applicant’s personal circumstances against seriousness of parental fraud
Crimes.Application_Error: Fraudulent representation leading to exclusion under family class provisions
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that relevant evidence was disregarded
Crimes.Legal_Standard: H&C discretion under subsection 25(1), with emphasis on best interests of child
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and impact of fraudulent representation on immigration eligibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Permanent residence denied due to lack of sufficient H&C justification
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of materially false or incomplete information in immigration forms

Sentencing_Issue: Pre-trial custody included in term of imprisonment

Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA
Legal_Rule: Pre-trial custody counts toward term of imprisonment
Grounds_for_Claim: IAD lacked jurisdiction due to serious criminality
Defendant_Response: Argued pre-trial custody should not count
Outcome: Deportation order upheld

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada due to serious criminality
Application_Facts: Ngoc Quang Nguyen sentenced to 18 months with 11 months pre-trial credit, total 29 months
Procedural_Issue: Jurisdiction to appeal based on sentence length
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction when serious criminality threshold is met
Evidence_Used: Sentencing record, pre-trial custody credit
Outcome: Deportation order upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Term of imprisonment includes pre-sentence custody
Decision_Rationale: Total effective sentence exceeds two years; pre-trial custody included
